dig.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to move earth, snow etc, or to make a hole in the ground, using a spade or your hands
dig.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: They dig a small hole in the sand to bury their eggs.
dig.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to remove something, especially vegetables, from the ground using a spade
dig.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to put your hand into something, especially in order to search for something
dig.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: She dug around in her bag for a pen.
He dug his hands deep into his pockets.
dig.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: to make a hole in the ground using your hands, a tool, or a machine
Some workmen were digging a trench at the side of the road.
In Africa, the people know where to dig for water.
to dig a hole in the ground, using your hands or a tool
Make a hole just big enough for the plant’s roots.
if an animal burrows, it makes a hole or a passage in the ground by digging the earth with its feet, nose etc
The rabbits had burrowed a hole under the fence.
to turn over the soil using a machine or a tool pulled by animals, to prepare the soil for planting seeds
The farmers here still plough their fields using buffaloes.
to dig a large hole in the ground, especially as a preparation for building something
The men began excavating the hole for the pool.
to make a deep round hole in the ground using a special machine, especially in order to look for oil or water
Companies need a special licence to bore for oil.
dig.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: a joke or remark that you make to annoy or criticize someone
dig.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: He couldn’t resist a dig at the referee.
Here was a chance to have a dig at trade unionists.
dig.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: an organized process of digging in order to find ancient objects for study
